header.title: Outsourcing — selection criterias
header.subtitle: A precise description of the criterias used for selecting vendors

section.title: Introduction
section.p: This document is written in conformance with the guidelines from the Norwegian ministry of trade and industry (Nærings- og handelsdepartementet, NHD) (see «Veileder», see link on the overview page).
The purpose of the selection criterias is to select the economically most appealling offer. The main criterion is price, but also indirect costs and longer term costs will influence the decision.
The selection criterias as well as the weighting are decided upon by the project board.

section.title: Selection criterias
section.p: The following criterias will be used in selecting the vendor(s) for contract work:

ol.li: Technical compatibility with our existing linguistic resources and language technology. The less compatible, the more work even for the project team, and thus higher indirect costs

Economical stability of the companies
This is more like a risk analysis thing - does it belong here?

The outlook for future, long-term cooperation with the companies (includes willingness to license tools to compile the binary lexicon for the proofing tools to Sámediggi and the project group, such that linguistic, non-technical updates can be delivered to end users without involment from the cooperating companies). This criterion involves costs in the longer run, and adds to the overall picture and maintenance costs for the proofing tools.

The future, long term relationship between the participating companies and the companies developing the software the proofing tools should be integrated with.
This is also more of a risk analysis type - it has no direct economical impact, but the risk is that the cooperation between company X and e.g. Microsoft is stopped, blocking company X from providing technical updates in the future.

Quality and user evaluation of corresponding tools for other languages. In the case of the InDesign hyphenator, it is essential that a company can provide a documented capability to develop high-quality hyphenation modules, benefitting from our linguistic work and tools. In the case of proofing tools for MS Office, it is important that the estimated quality of the end user products are high enough for our end users, to reduce the risk of extra work and higher costs later on in the project.
Again, this might belong somewhere else, but at the same time, this point should have an impact on which company to select.

Ability to provide the spellers with corrections and additional suggestions tailored to spelling errors typical for (modestly) dyslectic writers.
This criterion is motivated by the fact that most of the adult Sámi population has never learned to write their own language, and have great difficulties spelling it correctly. It is an explicit goal of the project to create spellers that will help this group, and if a provider does not have a framework for correcting and making suggestions for such spelling errors, much more work will have to be put into finding and studying these errors, and adding manual entries for correcting such errors. This will lead to higher costs, both for the chosen company and for the project team at Sámediggi.

section.p: The exact documentation needed to support a decision based on these criterias is specified in the main public tender document.

section.title: Weighting of the criterias
section.p: The above criterias are given a certain weight according to the following list (in the same order):
For each criteria, the companies are ranked as winners and loosers - winners normally get the full score, while loosers get nothing unless otherwise stated - within the following limits:

ol.li: prize differences within 2% will be regarded as equal, and all within that limit will be regarded as winners

technical compaatibility will be scaled as follows:
can use our lexicon (with trivial adjustments): 5%
can use our two-level rules (with trivial adjustments): 10%
can use our morphological description (with trivial adjustments): 5 %
Each company will receive a total precentage corresponding to the sum of the above sub-criterias.
The most stable company according to the NHD risk analysis model and requested documentation (see the main public tender document) is the winner

Proposal for long-term cooperation:
lowest cost: 5 %
most useful toolset and best license conditions: 5 %
Each company is a winner or looser in each sub-criterion. 5 % variation is allowed for the cost, similar to the 2 % above for prize. If two or more companies are deemed equal, they all get full points.
The company with the best documented, past and future long-term relationship with Microsoft is the winner.
In the absence of established standards for user evaluation of proofing tools, the company with the best published or otherwise documented user feedback on their tools is the winner
The company with the best published or otherwise documented algorithms for suggestion mechanisms for dyslectic or otherwise weak writers is the winner.

section.p: The winning company is the one with the highest total score, that is, the sum of the score for each criterion.

section.title: The final word
section.p: If two or more companies get identical scores, the final decision is made by the project board on the basis of a total evaluation of each remaining offer.
